Text.Language: He had a daughter who was a believer. This was St.Â Barbara, the wise maiden. She renounced this short existence, and hoped to win everlasting life. She did not fear the might of her father, nor his severity, nor his punishment, but confessed (faith) in Jesus Christ, Son of the living God, King of heaven and earth. The governor tortured her severely. Later, she completed her seeking, and her head was severed with the sword. She received the crown of martyrdom on the eighth day of Koiahk in peace from God. A fire came down from heaven, from Jesus Christ, and burned both the king and her father. A group of believers came and took the body and placed it in the church.

She cut her hair and came before the idols, so that they might address her with regards to the marriage and concerning the wedding. And when they did not talk to her, she raised her eyes toward heaven and said: "Help me and make me succeed in doing what pleases you, O God of the Christians." An angel came to her and said to her: "Tomorrow, a disciple of Paul the apostle will come to this city. He will baptize you in the name of Jesus Christ." The disciple came to her and informed her of mysteries and of what was to happen to her. When her father came to her as had been agreed, she let him know openly that: "I have become a Christian." He took her out of the tower and tortured her severely. When no evil befell her, her father the king believed in Christ. This virgin received tortures of every kind. Christ performed great miracles and many wonders by her hands. As for those who believed because of her, they numbered one hundred thirteen thousand. She reposed later with great glory and much honor.

This saint was from Zorari+, a son of two faithful god-loving parents. They used to commemorate the angel Michael on the twelfth day of every month, and on that day, they used to give much more to feed the hungry and clothe the naked. The mother of the saint was called Sarah. Because of her meekness and beauty they called her Agzia Haraia, which means â€˜Godâ€™s Chosen One.â€™ She used to arise early every day to go to the church to worship before the Lord. She prayed thankfully with a tongue that does not grow silent, so that He might grant her a blessed son. The Lord accepted her prayer and she conceived this saint, and gave birth to him on the twenty-fourth day of Koiahk. From his youth, he started reading the Holy Scriptures, Godâ€™s breath. When his mother was reposed, he performed many acts of worship: much fasting and hard acts of asceticism. He did not neglect any of the virtues of heavenly or earthly beings. In the days of our father Abba Cyril, bishop of the lands of Ethiopia, he ordained him a priest, as the angel Michael instructed him. Thus, the Virgin Mary and the angel Michael helped him and guarded him.

Thus, they both went together and distributed their money to the poor and the weak, and they became monks. When Abba Benjamin grew up, he wanted to be counted among the martyrs. He rose and went to the deputy, and confessed openly before him (his faith) in Christ. He beat him severely, and threw him in prison. When his parents and his sister Eudexia heard of (what happened to) him they hurried and came to him. When they saw him suffering, they wept bitterly, and he consoled them. The deputy arrested them, and instantly ordered their heads be severed. Thus, they completed their struggle with the saint, on the twenty-seventh day of the month of Mesore. They received the crown of martyrdom and reigned with Christ in His kingdom.
